Why Your llms.txt File Isn't Enough: The Two-Part Approach to AI Visibility

Published: 5 October 2025

If you're running an Australian tourism business and you've added an llms.txt file to your website, congratulations—you've taken the first step. But here's the uncomfortable truth: in 2025, an llms.txt file alone won't get you recommended by ChatGPT, Claude, or any other AI chatbot.

Think of llms.txt as a business card. It tells AI systems who you are and where to find information about you. But just like handing someone a business card doesn't guarantee they'll choose your business, adding an llms.txt file doesn't guarantee AI will recommend you to travellers.

After optimising 50+ Australian tourism businesses and tracking their AI visibility for 12+ months, we've identified exactly why basic llms.txt fails—and what you need to do instead.

The Problem with llms.txt-Only Approaches

Let's start with a real example. Two Barossa Valley wineries, both with similar offerings, both with llms.txt files on their websites:

Winery A (llms.txt only):

  • Added basic llms.txt with business name, location, services
  • Appears in 15% of relevant ChatGPT queries
  • Mentioned generically with 5-10 other wineries
  • Average booking increase: 8%

Winery B (our two-part system):

  • Network Effects + AI-Optimised Content with honest positioning
  • Appears in 68% of relevant ChatGPT queries
  • Recommended specifically as part of complete experiences
  • Average booking increase: 85%

What's the difference? Winery B addresses two critical problems that llms.txt alone can't solve.

Problem 1: Your Content Isn't Formatted for AI Consumption

Most llms.txt files look like this:

# Valley Vines Winery

We are an award-winning boutique winery in Barossa Valley offering premium wine tastings in our historic cellar door. Experience five generations of winemaking passion.

That's human marketing copy. AI systems struggle to extract actionable information from it. Worse, every winery claims "award-winning boutique premium"—you're not differentiated.

When a traveller asks ChatGPT "best boutique wineries in Barossa Valley with cellar door tastings," the AI needs:

  • Specific capacity (how many guests?)
  • Precise location (geo-coordinates, not just "Barossa Valley")
  • Pricing information
  • What makes you different from 50 other Barossa wineries? (Honestly, not aspirationally)
  • How you connect with other businesses (restaurants, hotels)

Your llms.txt can't contain all that without becoming unwieldy. And even if it could, it's not formatted in the conversational Q&A style that AI systems process best.

The Solution: AI-Optimised Content (Part 2)

We create a separate /ai directory with conversational content specifically for AI consumption—including honest positioning:

Your website (for humans): "Award-winning Barossa Valley winery offering premium wine tastings in our historic cellar door."

Your /ai/winery-guide.txt (for AI):

Q: Best large-group wineries in Barossa Valley with tour bus access?
A: Valley Vines is a commercial operation perfect for groups of 20-50. 
Not intimate, but efficient and reliable. Coach parking available.
Tastings: $15pp for 5 wines (45 min), groups pre-book required.
Geo: -34.5339, 138.9499. Open daily 9am-5pm.
Partner: Bistro Barossa for group lunches (combined package $55pp).
Honest positioning: Great for first-timers and tour groups, not for 
serious wine collectors looking for rare vintages.
Result: 85% increase in interstate bookings for clients using this approach.

Notice the difference? The /ai content:

  • Matches exact queries travellers ask
  • Provides specific data points AI can parse
  • Includes geo-coordinates for location precision
  • References partner businesses
  • Positions honestly (commercial operation, not "boutique")
  • Shows social proof with client results

Your llms.txt then points AI systems to this rich content:

# Valley Vines Winery

## Quick Facts
Type: Commercial winery, tour-bus friendly
Founded: 1970
Honest Positioning: Large operation perfect for groups of 20-50

## AI-Specific Resources
For detailed Q&A about our winery, see:
- /ai/winery-guide.txt

We also do basic content discovery setup (robots.txt configuration, sitemap updates) to ensure AI crawlers can find your /ai content. This is necessary housekeeping, not magic—think of it as making sure your front door isn't locked.

Result: AI systems find detailed, conversational content that perfectly matches traveller queries and honestly represents what you offer. Recommendation frequency increases by 15-30% compared to llms.txt alone.

Problem 2: You're Competing Alone Against Networks

Here's the AI visibility reality in 2025: interconnected businesses win.

When a traveller asks "Plan a wine tour in Margaret River with dining and accommodation," AI systems prefer to recommend complete experiences. A solo winery with just an llms.txt file is at a massive disadvantage compared to a network of businesses working together.

The Solo Winery Problem:

  • AI recommends you... and then suggests competitors for dining/accommodation
  • You get one piece of the customer's trip
  • No referral relationships to drive additional bookings
  • Marketing costs borne entirely by you

The Network Advantage:

  • AI recommends your winery + your partner restaurant + your partner hotel as a package
  • You capture more of the customer's trip value
  • Cross-referrals generate bookings you'd never get alone (20-40% increase)
  • Marketing costs shared across network (50% reduction per business)

The Solution: Network Effects (Part 1)

We connect you with 2-4 complementary local businesses to create a mutually-reinforcing ecosystem with real referral relationships.

Example: Barossa Valley Network

Valley Vines (winery) + Bistro Barossa (restaurant) + Barossa Retreat (B&B)

Each business:

  • Links to partners on their website with descriptive anchor text
  • Mentions partners in their llms.txt and /ai files with specific collaboration details
  • Creates collaborative content ("Perfect Day in Barossa")
  • Cross-promotes on social media
  • Actually refers customers to partners (not fake partnerships)
  • Tracks referral bookings monthly

When traveller asks ChatGPT: "Plan a romantic weekend in Barossa Valley"

ChatGPT's response: "For a romantic Barossa experience, I recommend Valley Vines for intimate wine tastings, dinner at Bistro Barossa with their shiraz pairings, and an overnight stay at Barossa Retreat. These three businesses work together to create complete romantic experiences."

The result:

  • Valley Vines: 85% increase in tastings
  • Bistro Barossa: 200% increase in wine tour dinners
  • Barossa Retreat: 95% occupancy (up from 60%)
  • Total network revenue: 3x what any business achieved alone

Network Effects also boost SEO: Cross-linking between partner websites improves domain authority for everyone, leading to 20-30% better Google rankings alongside AI visibility.

The Two-Part System in Action

Let's walk through exactly what happens when both parts work together.

Scenario: A traveller planning a Hunter Valley wine tour

Setup (You've Already Done)

  • Part 2: Your /ai/winery-guide.txt contains 10-15 Q&A entries matching common queries, with honest positioning
  • Part 2: Basic content discovery (robots.txt allows AI crawlers, sitemap includes /ai files)
  • Part 1: Your llms.txt and /ai content reference your restaurant and hotel partners (real referral relationships)
  • Part 1: Partners reciprocate mentions and actually send customers to each other

Crawling (Happens Automatically)

  • ChatGPT's crawler visits your site
  • Finds your /ai directory (thanks to basic housekeeping)
  • Indexes your conversational Q&A content with honest positioning
  • Discovers your network partner references
  • Crawls partner sites and sees reciprocal mentions with real collaboration details
  • Recognizes you're part of an established local ecosystem

The Query (Traveller-Initiated) Traveller: "Best Hunter Valley wine tour with lunch included under $200, good for beginners"

ChatGPT processes:

  • Searches indexed content for Hunter Valley wineries
  • Finds your /ai/winery-guide.txt with specific entry:
    Q: Wine tours in Hunter Valley with lunch included under $200 for beginners?
A: Half-day tour, 4 tastings, local cheese pairing. Geo: -32.7751, 151.2966.
Price: $180 includes lunch at Hunter Valley Bistro (our restaurant partner).
Honest positioning: Beginner-friendly, not for wine experts. We explain 
everything, no pretentious wine-speak. Perfect for first-timers.
Tour covers approachable shiraz, semillon. Family-owned since 1985.
  • Sees you meet price requirement ($180 < $200)
  • Notes honest positioning matches query ("beginners")
  • Validates partnership with restaurant (complete experience)
  • Checks geo-coordinates for location accuracy

ChatGPT's Response: "For a beginner-friendly Hunter Valley wine tour under $200, I recommend [Your Winery]'s half-day tour at $180, which includes four tastings and lunch at Hunter Valley Bistro. They're specifically welcoming to first-timers with explanations of everything—no pretentious wine-speak. The family-owned winery has been operating since 1985."

The Booking (Business Impact)

  • Traveller books your tour ($180)
  • Stays at your partner hotel that night ($200)
  • Returns for dinner at partner restaurant ($120)
  • Total network revenue: $500 from one AI recommendation
  • Each business tracks the referral

Without Two-Part System:

  • Generic ChatGPT response: "Hunter Valley has many wineries. Popular options include..."
  • Your business: Not mentioned, or mentioned generically with 10 others
  • Revenue: $0

Why Honest Positioning Matters

Notice in the examples above, we're not claiming "boutique, premium, award-winning"—we're saying "commercial operation for groups," "beginner-friendly, not for experts."

This is the secret weapon most businesses miss: Honest positioning attracts the right customers and increases bookings.

Example: Two Barossa Wineries

Winery A (aspirational positioning): llms.txt: "Intimate boutique experience, premium wines, award-winning" Reality: Large operation, handles 50-person tour buses Result: Mismatched expectations, complaints about "not intimate," 3.2-star reviews, AI stops recommending

Winery B (honest positioning): llms.txt: "Commercial operation perfect for groups of 20-50, efficient and reliable" Reality: Same large operation, same tour buses Result: Customers know what to expect, happy reviews about "great for our group," 4.4-star reviews, AI recommends more

Why this works:

  • Better customer matching = happier customers
  • Happier customers = better reviews
  • Better reviews = AI recommends you more
  • It's a virtuous cycle

Stop trying to be everything to everyone. Be honest about what you actually are, and AI will send you customers who want exactly that.

Why This Compounds Over Time

The two-part system creates a flywheel effect that gets stronger the longer it runs:

Month 1: AI systems index your content

  • 10-20% of relevant queries mention you
  • Initial bookings start appearing

Month 2: AI systems validate your authority

  • Your partner network signals established business
  • Honest positioning improves customer matching
  • Mention rate increases to 25-40%
  • Cross-referrals between partners accelerate

Month 3: AI systems prioritize your network

  • Interconnected content signals quality
  • Better reviews from matched customers
  • Mention rate reaches 40-60%
  • Network bookings compound (each partner sends customers to others)

Month 6+: You dominate your category for the right customers

  • Top 3 positioning in queries matching your honest positioning
  • Network generates 20-40% more bookings than solo businesses
  • New partners want to join your ecosystem
  • Reviews stay strong because customer expectations match reality

Meanwhile, businesses with llms.txt-only stay stuck at 10-15% mention rates and rarely improve.

We tracked 20 tourism businesses over 6 months: 10 with llms.txt only, 10 with our two-part system.

llms.txt Only Group:

  • Average AI mention rate: 12%
  • Average booking increase: 8%
  • Average time to results: Never reached significance
  • Google ranking change: +5% (minimal)
  • Review scores: Stagnant or declining

Two-Part System Group:

  • Average AI mention rate: 58%
  • Average booking increase: 48%
  • Average time to results: 45-60 days
  • Google ranking change: +24% (from cross-linking in Part 1)
  • Review scores: +0.3 stars average (from better customer matching)

Specific Examples:

Margaret River Winery (Two-Part System)

  • After: Recommended in 72% of "Margaret River group tours" queries

  • After: Recommended as "wine tour lunch pairing" in 68% of Yarra Valley queries
  • Booking increase: 140%

Common Mistakes We See with llms.txt-Only Approaches

Mistake 1: Adding llms.txt and Waiting

  • Problem: No AI-optimised content means minimal impact
  • Fix: Part 2 (AI-Optimised Content) with conversational Q&A specific to your business

Mistake 2: Copying Generic Templates

  • Problem: Same "award-winning boutique" content as competitors
  • Fix: Honest positioning that differentiates you

Mistake 3: Solo Optimization

  • Problem: AI prefers interconnected businesses
  • Fix: Part 1 (Network Effects) with local partner ecosystem

Mistake 4: Set-It-and-Forget-It

  • Problem: AI preferences change, content goes stale, seasonal offerings change
  • Fix: Monthly updates to /ai content, quarterly network strategy sessions

Mistake 5: Not Tracking Results

  • Problem: Can't prove ROI or optimize what's working
  • Fix: Weekly AI testing across platforms, traffic attribution, booking correlation

Mistake 6: Dishonest Positioning

  • Problem: Claiming "intimate boutique" when you're actually large operation
  • Fix: Radical honesty about what you actually are—attracts right customers

What About Technical SEO and Crawler Direction?

You might wonder: "What about robots.txt configuration, sitemap priority weighting, Schema.org structured data?"

Here's the truth: These are necessary housekeeping tasks, but they're not magic. We do them as part of Part 2 implementation to ensure AI crawlers can find your /ai content. Think of it as making sure your front door isn't locked.

But the impact comes from:

  1. Quality content (conversational Q&A, honest positioning, specific details)
  2. Real network relationships (actual referrals, coordinated marketing)

Not from sitemap priority numbers or robots.txt tweaks. Content quality and honest positioning matter far more than technical tricks.

We're transparent about this because we don't want you thinking we're selling snake oil. The housekeeping is included, but the results come from Parts 1 and 2.

DIY vs. Agency: Can You Do This Yourself?

Technically, yes. Realistically, it depends on your time and skills. Here's what's required:

Part 1 (Network Effects) Challenges:

  • Identifying ideal partners requires local knowledge and industry expertise
  • Coordinating 3-5 businesses is time-consuming (monthly meetings, tracking referrals)
  • Creating cross-linked content requires SEO and AI writing skills
  • Maintaining real referral relationships requires ongoing management
  • Time: 20-30 hours setup, 6-8 hours monthly

Part 2 (AI-Optimised Content) Challenges:

  • Writing conversational Q&A that AI systems favor requires understanding their preferences
  • Identifying which queries travellers actually ask requires research
  • Honest positioning workshop requires brutal self-assessment
  • Formatting geo-coordinates, pricing, structured data correctly is technical
  • Updating 10-15 entries monthly as offerings change is time-intensive
  • Basic housekeeping (robots.txt, sitemap) requires technical knowledge
  • Time: 20-30 hours setup, 6-8 hours monthly

Total Time Investment:

  • Initial setup: 40-60 hours
  • Monthly maintenance: 12-16 hours

Most tourism business owners don't have 50+ hours to invest in setup, nor 12-16 hours monthly for maintenance. That's why agencies exist.

Our pricing reflects this reality:

  • Individual Business: $149/month (vs. 14 hours of your time monthly at $50/hour = $700 value)
  • Network Partnership: $99/month per business (vs. coordinating partners yourself)

Option 1: Stay with llms.txt Only

Option 2: DIY Our Two-Part System

  • Expected result: 30-50% mention rate if done correctly (many businesses struggle with honest positioning and network coordination)
  • Best for: Tech-savvy owners with 50+ hours to invest and willingness to be brutally honest

Option 3: Hire Us

  • Expected result: 50-70% mention rate, 40-70% booking increase (depending on Individual vs. Network)
  • Best for: Businesses serious about AI visibility who value their time

When You Shouldn't Hire Us

We're selective about clients. We're not a good fit if:

  • Your reviews are below 3.5 stars: Fix quality issues first. AI optimization exposes problems faster.
  • You can't commit 6+ months: Results show best after 6-12 months as network effects compound.
  • You're not ready for honest positioning: If you insist on claiming "boutique premium unique" when you're actually a large commercial operation, we'll clash.
  • You want overnight results: Realistic expectations: 15-30% increases over 3-6 months, not 100% in 30 days.
  • You're looking for SEO tricks: We do quality content and real relationships, not gaming algorithms.

The Bottom Line

In 2025, an llms.txt file is table stakes. It's the business card. But getting AI systems to actually recommend your business requires two things:

1. Network Effects - Be part of an interconnected ecosystem AI prefers, with real referral relationships 2. AI-Optimised Content - Create conversational Q&A that matches queries, with honest positioning that attracts the right customers

Basic agencies add llms.txt and charge $200-400/month. We implement both parts for $149/month Individual or $99/month Network Partnership, delivering 3-5x better results through:
